review_title: Join if you love to work non-stop
pros:
- Good health insurance and pention scheme
- It's easy to be in contact with the management
- WFH expenses
- Company gifts
cons:
- The company is not transparent regarding bonus.
- If you get promoted you won't have a salary raise straight away.
- Managers have more than 20 analysts in charge, and there are no roles such as 'manager assistant' to support on this.
- Apart from having a numerous team, managers have to work in other several projects.
- Expect to work extra time with no extra pay everyday unless you are a Quality Analyst.
- Quality Analyst role is actually a Content moderator role.
- The company is growing exponentially and it's slowly feeling like if you're working for a vendor such as CPL, Accenture, Cognizant, etc.
- No proper training in tools to work, usually they will ask you to work in something you have no idea how to use, with no training or good explanation on how to.
- No life/work balance as you need to be aware if somebody send you a message, even on weekends and while you are on holidays.

pros: The company has a leading B2C solution across the globe (TikTok), and heavy hiring plans that come from the cash rich advertising revenues and other 'data' agreements. The company is incredibly large, so scope for horizontal movement could potentially be very good if you are looking to come in and reskill over the course of a couple of years.
cons:
You will quickly realise, as per other reviews - this company has no concern for the wellbeing of its employees or the morality/ethical practice of business. They simply want route to cash as quick as humanly possible - and it shows. At a macro level you may hear of 'copycat' softwares coming out of this region, and this company is in the epicentre of it. Competitor analysis took a new meaning here, as to define every single move and practice the company made.

The company is heavily skewed towards Chinese employees, for which they have exported to every corner of the globe to attempt to maintain a stranglehold control on the management layer of the business. I would estimate that 90% of the management at the company is Chinese and to your eyes, seem vastly underqualified for their roles otherwise. Make no mistake, if you do not speak Mandarin at this company - your views will not be trusted or taken into consideration. You will be an 'outsider'. Note that even the American TikTok CEO lasted only a month before resigning. 

Despite being a senior hiring manager, I did not get the final say on who I would employ, what their duties were to be, or be seen to achieve if I set up my employees to be successful. I would be seen as 'in competition' with the people I hired the entire time.

Aside from the issues above, there are wider problems. The company suffers from a deep lack of transparency. We would often find out about major company changes or moves from popular news platforms before we would get any kind of internal notification (if acknowledged at all) and there is a general secretive nature about the business which unsettles both employees and prospective customers.

If you are not Chinese, and are expecting to make this company successful outside of the Chinese regions for a product which is not core (TikTok advertising) I would strongly suggest you considering other employment opportunities. You will have limited scope for success, growth and otherwise gain experience which is not relevant to other companies at this business.

review_title: Be careful if you're not in TikTok
pros: - High salary and excellent benefits.
cons:
- If you're joining ByteDance to work on something that isn't in TikTok think twice about it. ByteDance pursues lines of business outside and unrelated to TikTok which it doesn't understand.
- Bureaucratic, preferring research and report writing over real market testing and validation. 
- Incompetent managers with no relevant experience.
- Hierarchical organization in which employees are seen and not heard.
- No information sharing or teamwork. Communication occurs only when orders are issued.
- Low quality talent.
- Strong China bias.
- No personal development.

review_title: Don't work here if you are an Engineer and not a Chinese speaker
job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: Smart coworkers, lunch and dinner provided
cons:
- Work-life balance is awful. Lots of impromptu meetings on the weekends with coworkers in China
- Pretty much all major business decisions take place at the Chinese HQ, and these meetings are conducted in Chinese. You will feel very disconnected from the product and culture of the company if you are not a Chinese-speaker.
- Little-to-no formal code review process; the company is more focused on short-term results than long-term maintenance. Bugs everywhere on the development pipeline with little documentation for them. They are reported through group chat and will only be addressed once coworkers in China have time on their hands (very rare).
- Compensation isn't on-par with the rest of Silicon Valley

pros:
- Very nice colleagues
- snacks, fresh fruit every now and then
- co-working office space in the centre of Berlin
- young, fast growing company
cons:
- Monotonous monitoring of videos, lack of variation and other duties, making you feel like a machine. Just soul-destroyingly boring and a waste of your talent, time and energy.  
- Working in two different shifts (8:00 - 17:00, 16:00 - 1:00)
- You have to work during weekends and holidays 
- You don't always get two consecutive days off, which makes it hard to reload your energy or have something like a private life. 
- Shift plans can be rearranged last minute and seem to be almost randomly organised. One week you will be working in the early shift, the next week in the late shift and so on. You can never tell. There is no basic rotation principle. Business needs have first priority, not the health of employees. 
- A general lack of communication between the management and employees. Management is more concerned with numbers and productivity goals than with the actual people who do the job, which is not very motivating. You don't feel part of the flow of information.  
- Tasks and responsibilities get handed out in a very random way.  
- "Personal growth and development"?  No one can tell at this point.

review_title: Worst company I've ever worked for. Avoid if you can.
pros:
-Free food
-Nice office
-Friendly US coworkers
cons:
-The most unorganized, unprofessional company I've even been associated with.
-No room for growth unless you're Chinese/based in China.  All decision makers/bosses are based in Beijing and due to the time difference most decisions are made overnight while you're unable to offer your input. 
-Most corporate communication is in Chinese so oftentimes you feel left out of important companywide information.
-The company has no strategy behind any of their decisions or at least it's kept secret and not communicated outside of upper management
-Young and inexperienced managers who have no idea what it's like to manage anyone and offer very little direction while setting unrealistic goals and setting employees up for failure (hitting 60% of your OKRs is essentially passing)
-Very rare to get a promotion and oftentimes you're just shuffled around within the company moving from product to product and don't have any say in the products you work on
-Upper management refuses to listen to any feedback or criticism. Anyone I know who has tried has been let go from the company.
-Chinese work culture is terrible working 12+ hours/day and 6 days/week, so US employees feel pressure to be "always on" and responsive at all hours of the day often responding to messages in the middle of the night
-The company relies too heavily on their AI and algorithms that never seem to work
-Non-existant HR to report complaints to

job_title: Growth Marketing Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- Great benefits & Competitive salary 
- Extremely fast paced culture so you will learn a lot (1 Month feels like 1 Year)
- Tiktok is growing so u get to be part of a product which is growing exponentially (Good brand to have on your resume)
- Free food 
- Young culture
- New office brings fresh energy
cons:
- Most decisions are taken in China - HQ in China
- Constant uncertainty due to US-China trade-war 
- Chinese team members tend to speak in Chinese so non-Chinese speakers can feel left out
- Competitive culture so everyone is trying to prove themselves fast and step on others toes
- 996 culture is rampant 
- You may not be able to work for US government/related companies in future since you were part of a Chinese company
- Pain of a growing global company. Something I have witnessed at Uber & Airbnb

review_title: Very fast and messy place to work
pros: Foodies, benefits and perks, no politics
cons:
- Chaotic. By this I mean both management and cooperations with other colleagues. The bi-month goals changed constantly and therefore created lots of chaos. Colleagues will drop random questions or tasks to you (one time, I was asked to be the interviewer of another team's candidates. Of course I rejected politely). Due to the fact that most leaders are very young (inexperienced), the management is therefore very chaotic. I was astonished how some leaders don't even understand the basics of business data ( like how to analyze funnel data) . In one word, if your tolerance for mess is low, do not come here. 

- Not a product-driven company. The company values tech over product/design. Most techs might throw technical tasks/questions to PMs. Seems to me that the product teams have no product architect members. 

- Overly reliance on documents/meetings. You will spend up to 30% of your time attending meetings. Long hours spent on document writing as well. 

- Working hour. If you look for work/life balance, do not come, because ByteDance offers none. 

- Lack of focus. You will have many tasks on-going at the same time, causing you and the team have no sense/possibility to focus on the most important objective. You will have little time thinking/discussing your work focus. Most are coming down from upper-level OKRs. This is not a company respecting independent judgement.

pros: There are good benefits and a handful of great teams with stellar individuals based out of Los Angeles.
cons:
Working here was the worst.

The culture is so toxic, as there's hardly any trust between anyone and the combative nature of most teams often mean not coming to productive agreements on important projects. In most departments the leadership is lackluster and in need of major improvement, with some team leads being extremely inexperienced, uncommunicative and antagonistic even to their own team. In some cases, it's common for individuals to take on initiatives overnight without consulting the team, leading to conflicts that often see other members pinned as lazy and unmotivated.

The daily expectation is to work long hours, usually with short notice regardless of holidays or time off, and to be always available with hundreds of requests to answer in the dead of night. Communication is extremely lacking between countries despite trying to mediate time zone differences, and grievances are hardly handled with any resolution.

Role expectations are cloudy at best. Any individual can reach out to you with tasks that don't fit your job description but you're expected to do it anyway, and do it fast without any questions or guidance under the guise of urgency. Reaching out for any clarification often results in no real answers, and whenever issues occur it gets blamed as your attitude and work ethic being poor. 

Growth doesn't seem possible as you're expected to never question your role or team structure, unless you "prove" yourself to be deserving of promotion against impossible standards. Expressing a desire to grow in your role or team gets shut down and you don't have a say if you're moved from projects, teams or departments without notice. When people leave they are easily replaced without proper consultation from team members. 

Do not work here, the shininess of being in a new and big tech company gets overshadowed quickly by the sheer amount of disrespect, poor treatment and general toxicity that occurs every day. The company must improve and make major changes immediately or else more qualified and talented employees will continue to leave.

job_title: Community Content Management Specialist in Berlin
pros:
- Psychologist available via phone.
- Centrally located.
- Free coffee, but no milk during weekends or holidays.
cons:
- Watching thousands of videos a night with horrible songs slowly but surely melts the brain. 

- Intense pressure to have a next to perfect accuracy. With badly translated guidelines and constantly changing rules, this is impossible.

- Stretching the limits of the law beyond imaginable. In the first week, I had to sign an appendix to the contract allowing ‘rotational’ shifts to be put in place, night work, work on holidays, work on weekends. It was either sign or resign. After a few months, these shifts have become standard. Only one person is “granted” to do the early shift for one week, maximum. Everyone else works in the night shift and on weekends plus holidays. Extra pay is the lawful minimum.

- Days off are completely random, could be a Monday and a Thursday this week. A Sunday and a Tuesday next week. 6/7 day in a row work weeks are commonplace.

- 6 month probation period, during which 70% of the team has been fired by the supervisor while they were sick or on holidays. The HR guy didn’t even bother to inform them.  

- During the job interview, the senior recruiter lies about “possibilities” in the company. But you have to wait out the 6 month probation period. After this, you’re told there are none. End of the line here.

-  Supervisor is incompetent beyond belief. Supervisors work hours are roughly from 11 to 18:00 hours. 99% of the team arrives at 16:00 and stays till 01:00. Who exactly are you supervising then? Doesn’t take the effort to get to know anyone, only communicates with favorites. Doesn’t know the very basics of the work we do after being on the job 6 months.

- Supervisor intimidates and lashes out at anyone who dares to be critical. Does not have any sense of self-criticism. Blames the whole world. Needs to be told by lower-ranking team members how to do job.

- Constant lies about reasons for radical changes or why there isn’t any new staff hired to take the pressure off the workload. Blame is always put on “China”, where in fact only the local supervisor decides these things.

- As the office in which its located doesn’t have staff operating after 17:00 the air-condition is either off and leaves it smelling like a dump or on freezer mode and leaves everyone sick. Windows can’t be opened. Dishes aren’t done during the weekends, toilets smell like a sewer.

- Pay is terrible, especially considering the toll it takes on personal health and family life.
